Weatherwalks - Ames
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES Vol 247 A

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 25. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPT. OF WESTERN CUBA,
Quemados, August 22, 1900.

1. Private Fred S. Gilman, Troop M, 2d U. S. Cavalry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Hamilton Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of desertion,
in violation of the 47th Article of War; and of introducing
liquor into his quarters and having his bedding, clothing
and equipment in a filthy condition, to the prejudice of
good order and military discipline, in violation of the 62d
Article of War, was sentenced “To be dishonorably discharged
the service of the U. S., forfeiting all pay and allowances
due him, and to be confined at hard labor, at such place as the
reviewing authority may direct, for the period of one year.”

The sentence is approved and will be duly executed. Fort
Columbus, New York Harbor, is designated as the place of
confinement. The prisoner will be confined at Hamilton
Barracks, Cuba, pending further orders.

2. Private Joseph L. Ashton, Troop A, 2d U. S. Cavalry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Hamilton Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of sleeping on
post, in violation of the 39th Article of War (one previous
conviction), was sentenced “To be confined at hard labor,
under charge of the post guard, for three (3) months, and to
forfeit ten ($10) dollars per month for the same period.”

The sentence is approved and will be duly executed at
the post where his troop is stationed.

3. Private William Kramer, Company H, 10th U. S. In-
fantry, having been tried by a general court-martial con-
vened at Rowell Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of de-
sertion, in violation of the 47th Article of War, and of lar-
ceny, to the prejudice of good order and military discipline,
in violation of the 62d Article of War, was sentenced “To
be dishonorably discharged the service of the United States, forfeit-
ing all pay and allowances due him, and to be confined at hard
labor, at such place as the reviewing authority may direct, for two
(2) years.”

The sentence is approved and will be duly executed. Fort
Columbus, New York Harbor, is designated as the place of
confinement. The prisoner will be confined at Rowell Bar-
racks, Cuba, pending further orders.

4. Private Edward Weatherwalks, Hospital Corps, U. S.
Army, having been tried by a general court-martial con-
vened at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of
obtaining from Quartermaster's Corral a team of mules and
buckboard, by falsely stating that he was authorized by
Acting Assistant Surgeon R. P. Ames, U. S. A., to get the
same; and while in wrongful possession of said property
causing said buckboard to become damaged to the extent
of ten dollars; and of being drunk, in violation of the 62d
Article of War (three previous convictions), was sentenced
“To be confined at hard labor, under charge of the post guard,
for three (3) months, and to forfeit ten (10) dollars per month
for the same period.”

The sentence is approved and will be duly executed. Co-
lumbia Barracks, Cuba, is designated as the place of con-
finement.

5. Private Francis G. Golding, Troop I, 7th U. S. Cavalry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of absence with-
out leave, in violation of the 32d Article of War; and drunk-
enness, to the prejudice of good order and military disci-
pline, in violation of the 62d Article of War (six previous
convictions), was sentenced “To be confined at hard labor,
under charge of the guard, for six (6) months, and to forfeit ten
(10) dollars per month for the same period.”

The sentence is approved. Three (3) months of the term
of confinement is remitted, the sentence being in excess of
the limit of punishment prescribed by law.

As thus mitigated the sentence will be duly executed at
the post where his troop is stationed.

6. Major W. S. Edgerly, 7th Cavalry, Acting Inspector
General, will proceed to Cabaña Barracks, Artillery Defenses
of Havana, to inspect certain unserviceable government
property reported at that post requiring the action of an
Inspector.

Upon completion of this duty Major Edgerly will rejoin
his proper station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

7. General Prisoner William Mahoney, late private Troop
A, 2d U. S. Cavalry, having been tried by a general court-
martial convened at Hamilton Barracks, Cuba, charged
with selling clothing, in violation of the 17th Article of
War, was acquitted.
The acquittal is approved.

8. Private Emil J. Rieken, Company G, 10th U. S. In-
fantry, having been tried by a general court-martial con-
vened at Rowell Barracks, Cuba, charged with larceny, to
the prejudice of good order and military discipline, in
violation of the 62d Article of War, was acquitted.

The acquittal is approved. The prisoner will be released
from confinement and restored to duty.

BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:
R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
